questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following vitamins have a hormonal action?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin D has hormonal action. In conjunction with parathyroid hormone, it is a major 
regulatory hormone for Ca2+ and phosphate metabolism.

questions.question: Question 2: The active form of vitamin D is
questions.explanation:
The active form of Vit D is 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. Cholecalciferol is formed in the skin and converted to 25 hydroxycholecalciferol in the liver. This 
is hydroxylated in the kidney to form 1,25-dihyroxycholecalciferol.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is false regarding actions of vitamin D?

options.a: Vit D receptor-retinoid X receptor complex binds to DNA and activates transcription
options.b: Vit D increases absorption of calcium from the intestine by increasing calbindin
options.c: Phosphate flux through the gastrointestinal epithelium is enhanced by vitamin D
options.d: Vit D decreases phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules

questions.explanation:
Vit D does not decrease phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules. It increases calcium and 
phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, leading to a decrease in excretion of these 
substances in the urine. 752 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with craniotabes, rachitic rosary and bowed legs. 
Diagnosis of rickets was made. To investigate the cause of rickets and to find the status of 
vitamin D in the body, which of the following should be measured?
questions.explanation:
Measurement of 25 hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) provides more accurate information about 
vitamin D levels. PTH is increased in vitamin D deficiency. PTH is a major stimulus for the 1 -hydroxylase, so there 
is increased synthesis of the active hormone, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Paradoxically, levels of this 
hormone are often normal in severe vitamin D deficiency. Therefore, measurements of 1,25- 
dihydroxyvitamin D are not accurate reflections of vitamin D stores and should not be used to 
diagnose vitamin D deficiency in patients with normal renal function.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following decreases the conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25 
dihydroxycholecalciferol?
questions.explanation:
The conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is done by enzyme 
1 -hydroxylase which is present in the kidney. In chronic renal failure (CRF), there is a deficiency 
of this enzyme and formation of the active form of vitamin D does not take place. Factors which increase activity of 1 -hydroxylase are: • Ca2+ deficiency • Increased parathyroid hormone (PTH)

questions.question: Question 6: Which organ is not involved in calcium homeostasis?
questions.explanation:
The lung is not involved in calcium homeostasis. There are two sources of cholecalciferol in the body: 753 
Sold by @itachibot • Diet • Synthesized in the skin from •-dehydrocholesterol in the presence of ultraviolet light. Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated in the liver to form 25-hydroxycholecalciferol, which is further 
hydroxylated in the kidney to forn 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. At higher calcium 
concentrations, when PTH is suppressed, the 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to a different 
compound—24,25dihydroxycholecalciferol— that has almost no vitamin D effect. Note: This is a controversial question because new evidence suggests an association between 
calcium homeostasis and pulmonary fibroblasts. Therefore: • If Lung is given in the options and spleen is provided as one of the choices instead of Kidneys, 
Skin, Liver or Intestine, then the best answer would be the spleen. • If other options are Kidneys, Skin, Liver, or Intestine, then the best answer would be Lung as the 
role of these organs in calcium metabolism is beyond doubt.

questions.question: Question 7: Increased calcium levels lead to
questions.explanation:
Increased calcium levels lead to an increase in 24,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol. The levels of calcium control formation of 1,25-dihydroxyxholecalciferol. When calcium is low, 
PTH (parathyroid hormone) promotes the conversion of 25hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25- 
dihydroxycholecalciferol□ in the kidneys. At higher calcium concentrations, when PTH is sup- 
pressed, the 25hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to a different compound—24,25- 
dihydroxycholecalciferol— that has almost no vitamin D effect. 754 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: What would be seen in a patient whose diet is deficient in calcium?
questions.explanation:
Low Ca2+ diet leads to hypocalcemia, which stimulates PTH release. Hence, this patient will have 
high PTH levels. Increased PTH causes • Hypophosphatemia due to increased excretion of phosphate via the kidneys. • PTH acts on the kidneys to increase the absorption of calcium. • PTH also increases the level of the enzyme 1- hydroxylase which leads to more production of 
the active form of Vitamin D- 1,25 dihydrocholecalciferol. In the presence of hypocalcemia, serum calcitonin levels decrease and active form of vitamin D 
increases. 755 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: In an experiment, a rat is infused with a small volume of a calcium chloride solution. 
Compared to the control condition, which of the following would result from the calcium 
load?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, increased formation of 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol will take place. Infusion of calcium chloride solution will lead to raised calcium concentration in blood. At higher 
calcium concentrations, PTH is also suppressed. So the 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to a 
different compound : 24,25dihydroxycholecalciferol— that has almost no vitamin D effect. When plasma calcium concentration is high, formation of 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is also 
greatly depressed. Lack of 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, in turn, decreases the absorption of 
calcium from the intestines, bones, and renal tubules, thus causing the calcium ion concentration 
to fall back toward its normal level. Option A: Since PTH levels are supressed bone demineralisation does not take place. Option B: Calcitonin is a calcium regulatory hormone whose level increases when the calcium 
concentration in plasma is high. Option C: Calcium ions are a part of the coagulation cascade and the blood coaguability either 
increases or remains the same with high plasma Ca+2 levels.

questions.question: Question 10: Calcium absorption takes place mainly from which of the following sites?
questions.explanation: Calcium absorption is mainly from the proximal small intestine (duodenum). Vit D and PTH are important factors that control calcium absorption.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is an enhancer of calcium absorption from the intestine?
questions.explanation:
Ca 2+ absorption is enhanced by proteins. It is inhibited by phosphates, phytic acid, and oxalates because these anions form insoluble salts 
with Ca 2+ in the intestine.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is the active form of calcium?
questions.explanation:
Ionic calcium is the active form that is important for most functions of calcium in the body, 
including the effect of calcium on the heart, the nervous system, and bone formation. Most of the calcium (99%) is stored in the bones. Only about 0.1 percent of the total body calcium 
is in the extracellular fluid and 1 percent is in the cells and its organelles. From the 0.1% Ca+2 in the plasma, the distribution of calcium is as follows: • About 41 % is combined with the plasma proteins (non-diffusible through the capillary 
membrane) 756 
Sold by @itachibot • About 9 % is combined with anionic substances of the plasma and interstitial fluids like citrate 
and phosphate in such a manner that it is not ionized (diffusible through the capillary membrane); 
and • The remaining 50 % of the calcium in the plasma is both diffusible through the capillary 
membrane and ionized.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following cells play a key role in bone resorption?
questions.explanation:
Osteoclasts play a key role in bone resorption. The cells responsible for bone formation are osteoblasts and the cells responsible for bone 
resorption are osteoclasts. Osteoblasts are modified fibroblasts. Osteoclasts are the members of the monocyte family Osteoclasts erode and absorb the previously formed bone • They become attached to the bone via integrins forming a sealing zone where the bone 
resorption takes place • Proton pumps (H+ -ATPases) then move from the endosomes of the osteoclasts into the cell 
membrane as opposed to the sealing zone and acidify the area to pH 4.0. • The acidic pH dissolves hydroxyapatite, and the acid proteases secreted by the cell break down 
collagen.

questions.question:
Question 14: On infusing parathyroid hormone in experimental mice, there is increased resorption of bone 
due to stimulation of the osteoclastic activity. Which of the following is true regarding the 
cellular mechanism of osteoclastic activation?

options.a: The bone-resorbing osteoclast cells do not have PTH receptors
options.b: Osteoclasts produce osteoprotegerin (OPG) a cytokine that increases bone resorption
options.c: RANK ligand and M-CSF are necessary for formation of mature osteoblasts
options.d: Glucocorticoids promote osteoblast activity and inhibit bone resorption

questions.explanation:
Osteoclast cells do not have PTH receptors. PTH stimulates osteoclast activity and bone 
resorption by an indirect mechanism. 757 
Sold by @itachibot PTH has receptors on the osteoblasts in the bone. When PTH binds to these receptors, osteoblasts 
release cytokines like RANK-ligand and M-CSF. These cytokines allow the differentiation of 
macrophages to osteoclasts. Osteoclasts, in turn, cut the collagen in the bone, which is bound to calcium. This causes the 
release of calcium, phosphorus, and collagen breakdown products in the blood. Osteoblasts produce osteoprotegerin (OPG), or osteoclastogenesis inhibitory factor, a cytokine 
that inhibits bone resorption by preventing interaction of RANKL with its receptor. PTH 
decreases the production of osteoprotegerin (OPG). Glucocorticoids promote osteoclast activity and increase bone resorption by increasing RANKL 
production and decreasing the formation of OPG. On the other hand, the hormone estrogen 
stimulates OPG production.

questions.question:
Question 15: A mouse is engineered to lack a transcription factor necessary for the normal development of 
osteoclasts. Compared to normal littermate mice, which of the following would be reduced in 
the knocked-out mouse?
questions.explanation:
Secretion of acid proteases would be decreased in the knocked-out mouse. Osteoclasts produce 
proteolytic enzymes and several acids necessary for bone resorption. The enzymes digest or 
dissolve the organic matrix of the bone, and the acids cause dissolution of the bone salts. A knocked-out mouse is a genetically modified mouse in which an existing gene is inactivated or 
'knocked out' by replacing it with an artificial one. The control mice used in the above case are 
littermate mice i.e mice with genetically modified embryonic stem (ES) cell strains used to test 
whether specific genes control a disease or immunological phenomena (eg: normal osteoclastic 
development) Option B: The acidic pH caused by the osteoclasts dissolves hydroxyapatite. In the knocked-out 
mouse, hydroxyapatite levels would therefore increase. Option A and C: Since the lineage of osteoclasts and osteoblasts is different, there is no decrease 
in the proliferation of osteoblasts. As the osteoblast levels are normal, phosphate deposition in 
bone also remains normal.

questions.question:
Question 16: 748 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is true regarding calcium homeostasis?

options.a: 90% of calcium is filtered from the glomerulus
options.b: Calcium is reabsorbed mainly from the late distal convoluted tubule (DCT)
options.c: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) promotes calcium reabsorption from the renal tubules
options.d: Calcitonin promotes action of parathyroid hormone

questions.explanation:
PTH promotes the reabsorption of calcium from the renal tubules. Option A: About 41 percent of the plasma calcium is bound to plasma proteins and is therefore 
not filtered by the glomerular capillaries. The rest of the calcium is filtered through the glomeruli 
into the renal tubules. Option B: Of the filtered calcium, approximately 90 percent is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules, 
loops of Henle, and early distal tubules. However, when calcium levels are low and PTH levels 
rise, PTH promotes calcium reabsorption from the later DCT. Option D: Calcitonin tends to decrease plasma calcium concentration and, in general, has effects 
opposite to those of PTH. 758 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not an effect of parathormone?
questions.explanation:
PTH does not increase phosphate reabsorption in kidney, rather it causes decreased phosphate 
reabsorption in the kidney.

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following will be most likely seen in a patient with parathyroid deficiency after 
inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery?

options.a: High plasma phosphate, low Ca2+ levels and tetanus
options.b: Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability, and Trousseau sign
options.c: High plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization
options.d: Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.explanation:
In a patient with parathyroid deficiency due to inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands, the 
clinical evaluation will show low Ca+2 level, tetany, trousseau sign, and high phosphate levels. PTH is released in response to low calcium levels. It increases the calcium levels by the following 
actions: Following signs can be elicited in hypoparathyroidism due to hypocalcemia (tetany): • Chvostek sign: Contraction facial muscles on tapping over facial nerve in front of the tragus of 
the ear • Trousseau sign: accoucheur’s hand position and painful carpopedal spasm by applying a 
sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure for 5 
minutes Note - In option A, tetanus is different from tetany. Tetanus is caused by infection with the 
bacteria Clostridium tetani The image below is showing Trousseau sign. 759 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which of these cause hypocalcemia?
questions.explanation:
Calcitonin has calcium-lowering effects and may cause hypocalcemia. It does so by inhibiting bone 
resorption (direct effect) Calcitonin is synthesized and secreted by parafollicular (clear) cells of the thyroid. Actions of 
calcitonin are as follows: • Inhibits osteoclasts, thereby decreasing bone resorption (direct effect) • Increases renal calcium excretion • Decreases calcium absorption by the kidneys and intestines ˜nder normal physiological conditions, calcitonin is more important in young individuals 
(compared to adults), and it may play a role in skeletal development. In addition, it may protect the bones of the mother from excess calcium loss during 
pregnancy. Bone formation in the infant and lactation are major drains on Ca 2+ stores. They 
would cause bone loss in the mother if bone resorption were not simultaneously inhibited by an 
increase in the plasma calcitonin level. 760 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: 749 
Sold by @itachibot A 5•-year-old lady with metastatic breast cancer develops nausea, vomiting and confusion. 
Further evaluation reveals severe hypercalcemia. IV hydration is initiated and calcitonin is 
added to her treatment plan. Which of the following best represents the role of calcitonin in 
lowering serum calcium level?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of hypercalcemia of malignancy, most probably due to 
metastatic breast cancer. Calcitonin exerts its calcium-lowering effect mainly by inhibiting bone 
resorption and helps in the management of hypercalcemia. This calcium lowering action of calcitonin is direct, by inhibiting the activity of osteoclasts. 
However, calcitonin also increases renal calcium excretion and decreases calcium absorption by 
the kidneys and intestines.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 30-year-old lady undergoes thyroidectomy due to suspected malignancy. A week after the 
surgery she develops a spasm of facial muscles on tapping over the facial nerve in front of the 
tragus. Which of the following is the reason behind her muscle hyperexcitability?
questions.explanation:
761 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical vignette is suggestive of chvostek sign, seen in hypocalcemia due to accidental 
parathyroid injury during thyroid surgery. The muscle hyperexcitability seen in hypocalcemia is 
due to increased permeability of cells to Na+. During thyroid surgery, parathyroid gland is prone to accidental injury due to proximity with the 
thyroid gland. Damage to the parathyroid gland will lead to a low PTH level and low Ca2+ level. 
When the ECF concentration of Ca2+ falls below normal, the nervous system becomes 
progressively more excitable. Because there is increased membrane permeability to Na+. This 
leads to easy initiation of the action potentials. The peripheral nerve fibres become so excitable that they begin to discharge spontaneously, 
initiating impulses that pass to the skeletal muscles to elicit tetanic muscle contraction. Tetany 
occurs usually when calcium concentration falls to 6 mg/dL.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is false regarding confounders affecting serum calcium level?

options.a: Total calcium concentration is altered by variations in the serum albumin concentration.
options.b: Forearm exercise can lead to falsely elevated ionized calcium levels
options.c: Hemoconcentration due to tourniquet results in a rise of serum calcium
options.d: Acidosis causes a decrease in the ionized calcium levels

questions.explanation:
Acidosis does not cause a decrease in the ionized calcium levels. Rather, alkalosis causes a 
decrease in the ionized calcium levels. Plasma proteins are more ionized when the pH is high (alkalosis), providing more protein anions 
to bind with and sequester free Ca2+. This causes a decrease in ionized calcium and may trigger 
symptoms of hypocalcemia. Option A: Total calcium concentration is altered by variations in the serum albumin concentration 
as 41% of calcium is bound to plasma proteins like albumin, hence changes in albumin 
concentration affects the serum calcium levels. The corrected calcium levels can be calculated as: Corrected calcium (mg/dL) = measured total Ca (mg/dL) + 0.8 (4.0 - serum albumin [g/dL]), where 
4.0 represents the average albumin level. Option B: Fist-clenching or forearm exercise can lead to falsely elevated ionized (free) calcium 
levels. Option C: A tourniquet is usually avoided while drawing blood for calcium measurements since 
hemoconcentration also leads to an increase in serum calcium levels.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following cells is involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity?
questions.explanation:
Osteoblasts are involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity. Osteoblasts produce receptor activator for nuclear factor B ligand (RANKL) and macrophage 
colony stimulating factor (M-CSF), which are necessary for formation of mature osteoclasts and 
hence osteoclastic activity. Specific receptors for parathormone are present only on the osteoblasts and not on osteoclasts.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of these is not a marker of bone resorption?
questions.explanation:
762 
Sold by @itachibot Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase is a marker for bone formation. Other markers of bone formation are: • Serum osteocalcin • Serum type 1 procollagen (C-terminal/N-terminal) Markers for bone resorption are: • ˜rinary hydroxyproline • ˜rinary total pyridinoline (P›D) • ˜rinary free deoxypyridinoline (DPD) • ˜rinary collagen type 1 cross-linked N-Telopeptide(NTX) • ˜rinary or serum collagen type 1 cross-linked C-Telopeptide (CTX) • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b International Osteoporosis Foundation has proposed serum CTX and serum PINP (Procollagen 1 
N-terminal peptide) to be used as reference markers of bone resorption and formation, 
respectively, for the assessment of fracture risk and monitoring therapy in clinical settings.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland, which causes primary 
hyperparathyroidism (not secondary). Secondary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by high levels of parathyroid hormone, to 
compensate for the low levels of serum calcium, due to some other underlying condition. Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism, include: • Chronic kidney disease: The damaged kidneys are unable to produce sufficient amounts of the 
active form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. This further causes hypocalcemia and 
triggers PTH secretion. • Vitamin D deficiency: Causes hypocalcemia, which triggers the increased secretion of PTH. • Lithium: May cause an increased set-point of calcium for parathyroid hormone suppression, 
which leads to parathyroid hyperplasia. 763 
Sold by @itachibot Male Reproductive Physiology
